elements.content: Synthesis and structural depiction of two new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), namely, [{Zn­(L)­(oba)}·4H2O]α (Zn-MOF-1) and [{Cd1/2(L)1/2(nipa)1/2(H2O)1/2}·(DMF)1/2(H2O)]α (Cd-MOF-2) (where L = N 2,N 6-di­(pyridin-4-yl)­naphthalene-2,6-dicarboxamide, 4,4′-H2oba = 4,4′-oxybisbenzoic acid, and 5-H2nipa = 5-nitroisophthalic acid) are reported. Both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 have been prepared by reacting ligand L and coligand 4,4′-H2oba or 5-H2nipa with the respective dihydrates of Zn­(OAc)2 and Cd­(OAc)2 (OAc = acetate). Crystal structure X-ray analysis discloses that Zn-MOF-1 displays an overall 2D → 3D interpenetrated framework structure. The topological analysis by ToposPro suggests a (4)-connected uninodal sql topology with a point symbol of {44·62} having 2D + 2D parallel polycatenation. However, crystal packing of Cd-MOF-2 adapted a porous framework architecture and was topologically simplified as (3,4)-connected binodal 2D net. In addition, both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 were proved to be multifunctional materials for the recognition of organic amines and in the fixation of CO2 to cyclic carbonates. Remarkably, Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 showed very good fluorescence stability in aqueous media and have shown 98 and 97% quenching efficiencies, respectively, for 4-aminobenzoic acid (4-ABA), among all of the researched amines. The mechanistic study of organic amines recognition proposed that fluorescence quenching happened mainly through hydrogen-bonding and π–π stacking interactions. Additionally, cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide in the presence of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 afforded up to 96% of cyclic carbonate within 24 h. Both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 exhibited recyclability for up to five cycles without noticing an appreciable loss in their sensing or catalytic efficiency.

elements.content: Two Zn and Cd MOFs have been prepared, structurally characterized, and exploited as multifunctional materials for the selective recognition of organic amines and CO2-to-cyclic carbonate transformation reactions to address the environmental issues.
elements.clean_text:
Two
Zn and Cd MOFs have been prepared, structurally characterized,
and exploited as multifunctional materials for the selective recognition
of organic amines and CO2-to-cyclic carbonate transformation
reactions to address the environmental issues.

elements.content: Environmental pollution has emerged as one of the foremost global problems of the present era. The release of harmful chemicals, generated from the industrial effluent, waste ignition, agricultural surfeit including fertilizers, and so on mainly causes the environmental issue. Due to their polar nature, organic amines have been widely exploited in diverse areas such as dyes, pesticides, pharmaceuticals, and fertilizers and in the syntheses of fine chemicals. Importantly, amines particularly ammonia and aniline are the main constituents of industrial coolants, livestock breeding, and fertilizer production. Hair-curing products such as dyes, etc. commonly contain aromatic amines, particularly, 4-ABA, which end up in waterways and affect the aquatic ecology. In addition, aliphatic amines, viz., methylamine, dimethylamine, trimethylamine, and triethylamine are also released into the waterways during the decomposition of seafood products. Therefore, the capability of detection of such amines in trace amounts ensures a safe environment. It is essential, therefore, to develop an effective, sensitive, economic, and consistent detection technique, as the existing instrumental techniques for the recognition of organic amines are quite expensive and require special methods for sample preparation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Environmental pollution
has emerged as one of the foremost global
problems of the present era. The release of harmful chemicals, generated from
the industrial effluent, waste ignition, agricultural surfeit including
fertilizers, and so on mainly causes the environmental issue. Due to their polar nature, organic amines have been widely exploited
in diverse areas such as dyes, pesticides, pharmaceuticals, and fertilizers
and in the syntheses of fine chemicals. Importantly,
amines particularly ammonia and aniline are the main constituents
of industrial coolants, livestock breeding, and fertilizer production. Hair-curing products such as dyes, etc. commonly contain aromatic
amines, particularly, 4-ABA, which end up in waterways and affect
the aquatic ecology. In addition, aliphatic
amines, viz., methylamine, dimethylamine, trimethylamine, and triethylamine
are also released into the waterways during the decomposition of seafood
products. Therefore, the capability of detection of
such amines in trace amounts ensures a safe environment. It is essential,
therefore, to develop an effective, sensitive, economic, and consistent
detection technique, as the existing instrumental techniques for the
recognition of organic amines are quite expensive and require special
methods for sample preparation.

elements.content: On the other hand, carbon dioxide (CO2), a greenhouse gas, responsible for global warming, contributes to an increase in environmental temperature. The current CO2 concentration in Earth’s atmosphere is almost 412 parts per million (ppm), which is increasing day by day. The excessive generation of CO2 from fuel combustion is one of the prime causes of CO2 enhancement in the environment. Therefore, the capture of CO2 and its conversion into fine chemicals or fuels, materials, utilization, and storage are the foremost goals that have attracted worldwide consideration of the scientific community.

elements.content: The development of new methodologies based on decreasing the amount of CO2 followed by a subsequent increase in economic utility is desperately needed. CO2 is a versatile C1 organic feedstock owing to its easy availability, low cost, nontoxicity, nonflammability, and simplicity in handling. Cycloaddition is an important reaction that represents the conversion of CO2 not only in cyclic carbonates but also in polycarbonates. The biodegradable nature of cyclic carbonates provides an additional advantage to these materials being produced due to the addition of CO2 to a particular epoxide. Therefore, the conservation of the environment constitutes neat and healthy surroundings and meets public challenges in the present time.

elements.content: In this regard, crystalline porous coordination polymers also known as MOFs are providing unique functional materials due to their fascinating topological properties and numerous industrial, environmental, and societal applications. The presence of π-electron density together with Lewis acidic metal sites in a particular MOF provide the opportunity to employ these materials as molecular receptors for a diverse range of assorted amines as well as catalysts for the fixation of carbon dioxide.
elements.clean_text:
In this regard, crystalline porous coordination polymers also
known
as MOFs are providing unique functional materials due to their fascinating
topological properties and numerous industrial, environmental, and
societal applications. The presence of π-electron density together with Lewis acidic
metal sites in a particular MOF provide the opportunity to employ
these materials as molecular receptors for a diverse range of assorted
amines as well as catalysts for the fixation of carbon dioxide.

elements.content: Based on the aforementioned fascinating discussion, new MOFs, namely, [{Zn­(L)­(oba)}·4H2O]α (Zn-MOF-1) and [{Cd1/2(L)1/2(nipa)1/2(H2O)1/2}·(DMF)1/2(H2O)]α (Cd-MOF-2), were synthesized. In addition, these MOFs displayed unique properties for the detection of aromatic amines apart from fixating CO2 to cyclic carbonates. Remarkably, Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 exhibited exceptionally high fluorescence stability in aqueous solutions with 98 and 97% quenching efficiencies for 4-ABA, respectively. Furthermore, cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide in the presence of Zn-MOF-1 and or Cd-MOF-2 offered up to 96% desired product in 24 h. Both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 are recyclable for up to five cycles without any appreciable loss in their efficiency.

elements.content: 4-(Aminomethyl)­pyridine, 2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid, 4,4′-oxybisbenzoic acid (4,4′-H2oba), 5-nitroisophthalic acid (5-H2nipa), dihydrates of Zn­(OAc)2, Cd­(OAc)2 [OAc = acetate], organic amines, epoxides and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) were procured from TCI, Sigma-Aldrich, Finar, HPLC, and AVRA chemicals. The solvents employed during the present investigation were purified according to literature protocols. Organic amines and epoxides were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded with a PerkinElmer FT-IR 2000 spectrometer. A Thermo Scientific FLASH 2000 Series CHNS-O Organic Elemental Analyzer was used to record the microanalytical data, whereas NMR spectroscopy data were recorded with the help of Bruker Avance (400 and 500 MHz) spectrometers. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were obtained using an SDT Q600 (V20.9 Build 20) instrument (Artisan Technology Group, Champaign, IL). A Shimadzu UV-1800 spectrophotometer was employed to collect the UV–visible absorbance spectra. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) investigations were carried out using a Fisher Scientific iCAP RQ ICP-MS instrument. The mass spectra were collected using a Waters SYNAPT G2S high-definition mass spectrometer. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and pore size distribution measurements were performed using a Quantachrome ASiQwin gas adsorption analyzer (version 5.21) at 77 K temperature. A PANalytical X’PertPRO X-ray diffractometer was used to record the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data, wherein samples were milled and exposed to a 2θ range of 5–50°.

Experimental Section
Materials
and Methods
4-(Aminomethyl)­pyridine, 2,6-naphthalene
dicarboxylic acid, 4,4′-oxybisbenzoic acid (4,4′-H2oba), 5-nitroisophthalic acid (5-H2nipa), dihydrates
of Zn­(OAc)2, Cd­(OAc)2 [OAc = acetate], organic
amines, epoxides and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) were procured
from TCI, Sigma-Aldrich, Finar, HPLC, and AVRA chemicals. The solvents
employed during the present investigation were purified according
to literature protocols. Organic amines
and epoxides were used without further purification. IR spectra were
recorded with a PerkinElmer FT-IR 2000 spectrometer. A Thermo Scientific
FLASH 2000 Series CHNS-O Organic Elemental Analyzer was used to record
the microanalytical data, whereas NMR spectroscopy data were recorded
with the help of Bruker Avance (400 and 500 MHz) spectrometers. Differential
scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data
were obtained using an SDT Q600 (V20.9 Build 20) instrument (Artisan
Technology Group, Champaign, IL). A Shimadzu UV-1800 spectrophotometer
was employed to collect the UV–visible absorbance spectra.
Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) investigations
were carried out using a Fisher Scientific iCAP RQ ICP-MS instrument.
The mass spectra were collected using a Waters SYNAPT G2S high-definition
mass spectrometer. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface
area and pore size distribution measurements were performed using
a Quantachrome ASiQwin gas adsorption analyzer (version 5.21) at 77
K temperature. A PANalytical X’PertPRO X-ray diffractometer

samples were milled and exposed to a 2θ range of 5–50°.

elements.content: Single-crystal data for Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 were collected at 295 K on a SuperNova, single source at offset/far, HyPix3000 four-circle diffractometer with a microfocus sealed X-ray tube using a mirror as monochromator and a HyPix3000 detector. The diffractometer was equipped with a low-temperature device and used Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). All data were integrated with Crysalispro, and a multiscan absorption correction using SCALE3 ABSPACK was applied. The structures were solved by dual methods using SHELXT and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods against F 2 by SHELXL-2014/7 using the Olex2 GUI. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, whereas hydrogen atoms were isotropically refined on calculated positions. The structure refinement data along with selected bond lengths, angles, and hydrogen-bonding details are provided in Tables S1–S3 of the SI. Crystallographic data for the structures reported in this paper were deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. CCDC 2114369 and 2114367 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/structures.

elements.content: Zn-MOF-1 was synthesized by reacting ligand L (5 mg, 0.0125 mmol), coligand 4,4′-H2oba (3.2 mg, 0.0125 mmol), and dihydrate of Zn­(OAc)2 (2.7 mg, 0.0125 mmol) in a mixture of solvents {DMF/MeOH/H2O in 3:1:1 (v/v) ratio} that was placed in a glass vial (5 mL) with a screw cap and heated in an oven at 70 °C for 48 h by the solvothermal protocol. After that, the resulting solution was cooled to room temperature at a cooling rate of 0.5 °C/min and colorless, block-shaped crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray study were collected. Yield: 12.3 mg (61.5% based on L); Anal. Calcd for C38H36N4O11Zn·2H2O: C, 55.25%; H, 4.88%; N, 6.78%. Found: C, 55.59%; H, 4.12%; N, 6.55%. FT-IR spectrum (selected peaks): 3441, 1642, 1539, 1405, 1230 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:

mmol), coligand 4,4′-H2oba (3.2 mg, 0.0125 mmol),
and dihydrate of Zn­(OAc)2 (2.7 mg, 0.0125 mmol) in a mixture
of solvents {DMF/MeOH/H2O in 3:1:1 (v/v) ratio} that was
placed in a glass vial (5 mL) with a screw cap and heated in an oven
at 70 °C for 48 h by the solvothermal protocol. After that, the
resulting solution was cooled to room temperature at a cooling rate
of 0.5 °C/min and colorless, block-shaped crystals suitable for
single-crystal X-ray study were collected. Yield: 12.3 mg (61.5% based
on L); Anal. Calcd for C38H36N4O11Zn·2H2O: C, 55.25%; H, 4.88%;
N, 6.78%. Found: C, 55.59%; H, 4.12%; N, 6.55%. FT-IR spectrum (selected

elements.content: Cd-MOF-2 was prepared by adopting an identical procedure to that of Zn-MOF-1, wherein ligand L (6 mg, 0.015 mmol), coligand 5-H2nipa (3.0 mg, 0.015 mmol), and dihydrate of Cd­(OAc)2 (4.0 mg, 0.015 mmol) were mixed in a solvent mixture of DMA/DMF/H2O in 3:1:1 (v/v) ratio in a glass vial (5 mL) with a screw cap and heated at 85 °C for 48 h in an oven. Then, the resulting solution was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.5 °C/min and block-shaped, colorless crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray analysis were collected. Yield: 10.9 mg (54.5% based on L); Anal. Calcd for C35H31CdN6O10 (with H2O and DMF): C, 52.02%; H, 3.87%; N, 10.40%. Found: C, 51.51%; H, 3.44%; N, 9.39%. FT-IR spectrum (selected peaks): 3441, 1641, 1612, 1533, 1369 cm–1.

elements.content: A homogeneous suspension of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 was made by suspending the powdered sample of MOFs (50 mg in 250 mL) in an aqueous solution followed by sonication at room temperature for 2–3 h. The fluorescence spectra were recorded using a PerkinElmer LS-55 fluorescence spectrophotometer having a slit width of 5 nm. Notably, Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 displayed recyclability for five consecutive runs, indicating that the pores of the concerned probe were not blocked with the analytes during the sensing study and were available for the free pass of analytes. The MOF sample was recollected by centrifugation and washed several times with methanol prior to further use. The solid-state photoluminescence studies for both MOFs were carried out by assessing their powder samples between two microscopic slides. The excited-state fluorescence intensity decay data were assimilated in the time domain using a Horiba Jobin Yvon Fluorocube time-correlated single-photon counting (TCSPC) fluorimeter. The (%) fluorescence quenching efficiency was calculated using the literature formula (I 0 – I)/I 0 × 100%, where I 0 and I are the maximum fluorescence intensities of concerned MOF in the absence and presence of the analyte, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Sensing Experiments
A homogeneous suspension
of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 was made by suspending
the powdered sample of MOFs (50 mg in 250 mL) in an aqueous solution
followed by sonication at room temperature for 2–3 h. The fluorescence
spectra were recorded using a PerkinElmer LS-55 fluorescence spectrophotometer
having a slit width of 5 nm. Notably, Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 displayed recyclability for five consecutive runs, indicating
that the pores of the concerned probe were not blocked with the analytes
during the sensing study and were available for the free pass of analytes.
The MOF sample was recollected by centrifugation and washed several
times with methanol prior to further use. The solid-state photoluminescence
studies for both MOFs were carried out by assessing their powder samples
between two microscopic slides. The excited-state fluorescence intensity
decay data were assimilated in the time domain using a Horiba Jobin
Yvon Fluorocube time-correlated single-photon counting (TCSPC) fluorimeter.
The (%) fluorescence quenching efficiency was calculated using the
literature formula (I
0 – I)/I
0 × 100%, where I
0 and I are the maximum fluorescence
intensities of concerned MOF in the absence and presence of the analyte,
respectively.

elements.content: The CO2-to-epoxide cycloaddition reactions were performed using oven-dried glassware under solvent-free conditions, wherein styrene oxide (0.21 g, 1.7 mmol), catalyst Zn-MOF-1 (0.013 g, 0.017 mmol), and cocatalyst TBAB (0.017 g, 0.052 mmol) were added to a round-bottomed flask that was sealed with a rubber plug. Then, the reaction temperature was increased to 45 °C in an oil bath and CO2 gas was plunged into the reaction mixture with the help of a needle connected to the CO2 balloon through the rubber plug. The CO2 balloon was freshly recharged after every 6 h, and the progress of the reaction was examined by employing thin-layer chromatography (TLC). After completion of the reaction (24 h), the reaction mixture was cooled and charged with CHCl3. The solid catalyst was recycled by centrifuging the mixture. The crude product was concentrated under reduced pressure and dissolved in CDCl3 and analyzed by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy and mass spectrometry. The product quantification was done by integration of the 1H NMR signals (exemplified in the SI). It is important to mention that the high selectivity for cyclic carbonate products was perceived, as no byproducts were identified by 1H NMR.
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure for the CO2-to-Cyclic Carbonate
Transformation Reaction
The CO2-to-epoxide cycloaddition
reactions were performed using oven-dried glassware under solvent-free
conditions, wherein styrene oxide (0.21 g, 1.7 mmol), catalyst Zn-MOF-1 (0.013 g, 0.017 mmol), and cocatalyst TBAB (0.017 g, 0.052
mmol) were added to a round-bottomed flask that was sealed with a
rubber plug. Then, the reaction temperature was increased to 45 °C
in an oil bath and CO2 gas was plunged into the reaction
mixture with the help of a needle connected to the CO2 balloon
through the rubber plug. The CO2 balloon was freshly recharged
after every 6 h, and the progress of the reaction was examined by
employing thin-layer chromatography (TLC). After completion of the
reaction (24 h), the reaction mixture was cooled and charged with
CHCl3. The solid catalyst was recycled by centrifuging
the mixture. The crude product was concentrated under reduced pressure
and dissolved in CDCl3 and analyzed by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy and mass spectrometry. The product quantification
was done by integration of the 1H NMR signals (exemplified
in the SI). It is important to mention
that the high selectivity for cyclic carbonate products was perceived,
as no byproducts were identified by 1H NMR.

elements.content: Ligand L was prepared as per the reported method, and the details are provided in the SI (Scheme S1). Both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 with formulas, [{Zn­(L)­(oba)}·4H2O]α and [{Cd1/2(L)1/2(nipa)1/2(H2O)1/2}·(DMF)1/2(H2O)]α, were prepared following the solvothermal protocol and using the mixed-ligand approach (). Further, Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 were well characterized by analytical and spectroscopic techniques (Figures S1–S10) and single-crystal X-ray crystallography. The FT-IR analyses of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 exhibited prominent bands between 1642–1612 and 1539–1533 cm–1, which are ascribed to the amidic groups (Figures S4 and S5). Further, the UV–vis absorption spectra of both MOFs and ligand L were recorded in DMSO and are shown in Figure S10. A comparison of the concerned spectra of Zn-MOF-1, Cd-MOF-2, and L suggested that there is no significant shift in the absorption features even after the coordination of d10 metal ions, i.e., Zn2+ and Cd2+. We reasoned that the experimental absorption features of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 are predominantly instigated due to ligand-based π → π* and n → π* transitions.

the details are provided

formulas, [{Zn­(L)­(oba)}·4H2O]α and [{Cd1/2(L)1/2(nipa)1/2(H2O)1/2}·(DMF)1/2(H2O)]α, were prepared following the solvothermal protocol
and using the mixed-ligand approach (). Further, Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 were well characterized by analytical and spectroscopic
techniques (Figures S1–S10) and
single-crystal X-ray crystallography. The FT-IR analyses of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 exhibited prominent bands between
1642–1612 and 1539–1533 cm–1, which
are ascribed to the amidic groups (Figures S4 and S5). Further, the UV–vis absorption spectra of both
MOFs and ligand L were recorded in DMSO and are shown
in Figure S10. A comparison of the concerned
spectra of Zn-MOF-1, Cd-MOF-2, and L suggested that there is no significant shift in the absorption
features even after the coordination of d10 metal ions,
i.e., Zn2+ and Cd2+. We reasoned that the experimental
absorption features of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 are predominantly instigated due to ligand-based π →
π* and n → π* transitions.

1

Preparation of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 Using
Ligand L, Respective Coligands 4,4′-H2oba/5-H2nipa, and Dihydrates of Zn­(OAc)2 and
Cd­(OAc)2

elements.content: To examine the stability and crystallinity of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, thermal (TGA and DSC) and powder XRD analyses were performed and their respective curves/patterns are described in Figures S6–S9. The thermogram of Zn-MOF-1 showed a weight loss of 12.35% (obs.), which closely matches ca. 13.05% in the temperature range of 30–100 °C. This weight loss is attributed to the discharge of six lattice-occluded water molecules per unit cell followed by disintegration of the framework architecture (Figure S6). Similarly, Cd-MOF-2 also demonstrated a preliminary weight loss of 10.27% (ca. 11.26%) for the discharge of one coordinated water and a lattice DMF molecule in the temperature range of 30–300 °C (Figure S6). In addition, the particular DSC curves of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 also show the corresponding losses in the form of exothermic peaks and thus corroborate the TGA results (Figure S7). Further, PXRD patterns of bulk samples of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 are well fitted with the simulated pattern acquired from single-crystal X-ray data (Figures S8 and S9), indicating the phase purity of bulk samples.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analyses and PXRD
Patterns
To examine the stability
and crystallinity of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, thermal (TGA and DSC) and powder XRD analyses were performed and
their respective curves/patterns are described in Figures S6–S9. The thermogram of Zn-MOF-1 showed a weight loss of 12.35% (obs.), which closely matches ca.
13.05% in the temperature range of 30–100 °C. This weight
loss is attributed to the discharge of six lattice-occluded water
molecules per unit cell followed by disintegration of the framework
architecture (Figure S6). Similarly, Cd-MOF-2 also demonstrated a preliminary weight loss of 10.27% (ca.
11.26%) for the discharge of one coordinated water and a lattice DMF
molecule in the temperature range of 30–300 °C (Figure S6). In addition, the particular DSC curves
of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 also show the corresponding
losses in the form of exothermic peaks and thus corroborate the TGA
results (Figure S7). Further, PXRD patterns
of bulk samples of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 are well fitted with the simulated pattern acquired from single-crystal
X-ray data (Figures S8 and S9), indicating
the phase purity of bulk samples.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that Zn-MOF-1 crystallizes in the non-centrosymmetric orthorhombic space group Pna21. The asymmetric unit of Zn-MOF-1 contains two half molecules of ligand L, two half molecules of coligand oba2–, a Zn2+ ion, and four lattice-occupied water molecules. As shown in , the Zn2+ ion shows a slightly distorted square pyramidal geometry, wherein the equatorial positions are engaged by three OCOO atoms of two different oba2– ligands and one Npyridyl stemming from ligand L, while the apical site is occupied by another Npyridyl atom of the second ligand L. The Zn–O bonds are in the range of 1.952(5)–2.310(9) Å, and Zn–N bonds are in the range of 2.053(6)–2.067(6) Å (Table S2). The crystal packing of Zn-MOF-1 reveals that Npyridyl atoms of ligand L dwell in anti-orientation to extend the network in one direction in a zigzag fashion with Zn2+···Zn2+ parting at 20.208 Å (b), while the network is extending in another dimension via oba2– ligands to form a 2D sheet framework.

Structural Description
of [{Zn­(L)­(oba)}·4H2O]α (Zn-MOF-1)
Single-crystal
X-ray analysis reveals that Zn-MOF-1 crystallizes in
the non-centrosymmetric orthorhombic space group Pna21. The asymmetric unit of Zn-MOF-1 contains
two half molecules of ligand L, two half molecules of
coligand oba2–, a Zn2+ ion, and four
lattice-occupied water molecules. As shown in , the Zn2+ ion shows a slightly
distorted square pyramidal geometry, wherein the equatorial positions
are engaged by three OCOO atoms of two different oba2– ligands and one Npyridyl stemming from
ligand L, while the apical site is occupied by another
Npyridyl atom of the second ligand L. The
Zn–O bonds are in the range of 1.952(5)–2.310(9) Å,
and Zn–N bonds are in the range of 2.053(6)–2.067(6)
Å (Table S2). The crystal packing
of Zn-MOF-1 reveals that Npyridyl atoms of
ligand L dwell in anti-orientation to
extend the network in one direction in a zigzag fashion with Zn2+···Zn2+ parting at 20.208 Å
(b), while
the network is extending in another dimension via oba2– ligands to form a 2D sheet framework.

elements.content: Interestingly, the packing analysis of Zn-MOF-1 reveals the undulating 2D layered structure, which is prevalent among the mixed-ligand coordination polymers. Each 2D sheet is polycatenated by two adjacent sheets (one above and the other below), leading to formation of an overall 2D → 2D polycatenated 3D framework. Each layer is undulating and wide enough at the ends to accommodate the two other sheets in parallel polycatenation via interpenetration. Notably, the structure of Zn-MOF-1 features channels with a cross section of 7.10 × 33.02 Å2, running along the crystallographic b-axis, wherein the lattice-occluded water molecules are residing (Figure S11). In addition, the topological analysis by ToposPro suggests a (4)-connected uninodal sql topology with the point symbol {44·62} having 2D + 2D, parallel polycatenation.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis discloses that Cd-MOF-2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmca. The asymmetric unit of Cd-MOF-2 comprises a half molecule of ligand L, a half molecule of nipa2–, a half of Cd2+ ion, a half-occupied aqua ligand, a half-occupied lattice-occluded DMF molecule, and a fully occupied water molecule in the crystal lattice. As revealed in , the Cd2+ ion exhibits slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, wherein the five equatorial locations are engaged by four OCOO atoms stemming from two different nipa2– coligands and one Npyridyl coming from the L ligand, while the apical sites are employed by the Npyridyl atom of another ligand L and one O atom from the aqua ligand. Ligand L is extensively disordered over two positions and binds to two symmetry-related Cd2+ sites, which are common for high-symmetry structures involving flexible ligands. The Npyridyl atom is on a twofold rotation axis. The Cd–O bonds are found to be in the range of 2.283(8)–2.595(10) Å, and the Cd–N bond is in the range of 2.300(13)–2.379(13) Å (Table S2). The crystal structure of Cd-MOF-2 states that the pyridyl moieties of the L ligand exhibit syn–anti-orientation with a Cd2+···Cd2+ separation distance of 21.098 Å (), which is slightly longer than that of Zn-MOF-1. Further, the amide groups of ligand L adopt anti-periplanar conformation similar to Zn-MOF-1.

disordered over two positions and binds to two symmetry-related Cd2+ sites, which are common for high-symmetry structures involving
flexible ligands. The Npyridyl atom is on a twofold rotation
axis. The Cd–O bonds are found to be in the range of 2.283(8)–2.595(10)
Å, and the Cd–N bond is in the range of 2.300(13)–2.379(13)
Å (Table S2). The crystal structure
of Cd-MOF-2 states that the pyridyl moieties of the L ligand exhibit syn–anti-orientation with a Cd2+···Cd2+ separation distance of 21.098 Å (), which is slightly longer than that of

elements.content: Herein, the coligand nipa2– bridges two Cd2+ ions in chelating mode with a Cd2+···Cd2+ separation distance of 10.231 Å and extends the framework along the crystallographic a-axis, while the L ligand is responsible for extending the framework along the c-axis in a zigzag fashion, resulting in an overall 2D framework structure. The stacking of such sheets along the b-axis via N–H···O hydrogen bonds (Table S3) between the amide NH and O carboxylate of coligand nipa2– resulted in the formation of a 3D framework. The stacking is further enforced by the π–π interactions (cg···cg = 3.698 Å) between the nipa2– ring and one of the aryl rings of the central naphthyl core. Moreover, the Cd-MOF-2 structure contains channels with a cross section of 11.72 × 20.62 Å2, running along the crystallographic c-axis, wherein the lattice-occluded DMF molecules reside (Figure S11). Moreover, the topology of the coordination network becomes complicated due to disordered ligand L as each of the ligands is connected to three Cd2+ rather than the usual two connected linkers. Thus, the network can be simplified by considering each disordered ligand as a (3)-connected node, while each of Cd2+ assists as a (4)-connected node to produce a (3,4)-connected binodal 2D net. In addition, the topological analysis by ToposPro suggests the standard representation of two possible unknown topologies [36,43,5-c net] and [216,35,45,5-c net].

elements.content: The coordination framework architectures, which are constructed from π-electron-rich ligand and d10 metal ions are very well known for their photoluminescent behavior. Therefore, we have investigated the fluorescence behaviors of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 in different organic solvents including water, and the results are exposed in Figures S12 and S13. As described in Figure S13, both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 demonstrate a broad emission band between 330 and 510 nm when excited at 290 nm in an aqueous suspension. Besides, we have also measured the fluorescence behaviors of ligand L and coligands H2oba and 5-H2nipa and compared their outcomes with Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 (Figures S13 and S14). Notably, we observed a major enhancement in the fluorescence intensity compared to free ligand L and coligands H2oba and 5-H2nipa. The emission peak shown by the studied MOFs may be credited to the intraligand π–π* transition, wherein the enhancement in the fluorescence intensity could be principally attributed to the interactions between the π-electron-rich framework of ligands and Zn2+/Cd2+ metal ions. In addition, we have also recorded the solid-state fluorescence profiles of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 at room temperature to rationalize the photoluminescent nature of d10 metal-based materials in the solid state. As shown in Figure S15, both MOFs exhibit a broad emission peak between 330 and 450 nm when excited at 290 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Properties
The coordination framework
architectures, which are constructed from π-electron-rich ligand
and d10 metal ions are very well known for their photoluminescent
behavior. Therefore, we have investigated the fluorescence
behaviors of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 in different
organic solvents including water, and the results are exposed in Figures S12 and S13. As described in Figure S13, both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 demonstrate a broad emission band between 330 and 510 nm
when excited at 290 nm in an aqueous suspension. Besides, we have
also measured the fluorescence behaviors of ligand L and
coligands H2oba and 5-H2nipa and compared their
outcomes with Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 (Figures S13 and S14). Notably, we observed a
major enhancement in the fluorescence intensity compared to free ligand L and coligands H2oba and 5-H2nipa.
The emission peak shown by the studied MOFs may be credited to the
intraligand π–π* transition, wherein the enhancement
in the fluorescence intensity could be principally attributed to the
interactions between the π-electron-rich framework of ligands
and Zn2+/Cd2+ metal ions. In addition, we have
also recorded the solid-state fluorescence profiles of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 at room temperature to rationalize
the photoluminescent nature of d10 metal-based materials
in the solid state. As shown in Figure S15, both MOFs exhibit a broad emission peak between 330 and 450 nm
when excited at 290 nm.

elements.content: The crystal structure reveals that both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 contain several fascinating features, for instance, (i) the presence of well-defined pores and channels able to facilitate the free passage of the amines, (ii) the presence of a π-electron-rich ligand framework architecture for the possible π–π stacking and other noncovalent interactions, (iii) the presence of Lewis acidic metal sites, (iv) the existence of basic amide functionality, and (v) their high thermal as well as solution stability along with strong emission of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 in organic suspensions. It is worth noticing, that we have examined the luminescence intensities of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 in several common organic solvents such as acetone, toluene, tetrahydrofuran (THF), n-butanol (BuOH), ethyl acetate, ethanol (EtOH), propanol, isopropanol, acetonitrile (ACN), dichloromethane (DCM), methanol, chloroform, N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA), N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), aniline, and water and noticed the strongest emission in aqueous suspensions (Figure S12). Noticeably, the emission intensity of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 increases in most of the solvents, while it drastically decreases in the case of aniline, which indicates that the fluorescence intensity is largely reliant on the small molecules, and we fortified to explore these materials as fluorescence-based molecular sensors for a wide range of organic amines (). Further, this quenching in the emission intensity of sensors Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 could be observed by the naked eye as their colorless solution immediately changed to reddish-brown (Figure S16).

Molecular Recognition of Organic Amines
The crystal
structure reveals that both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 contain several fascinating features, for instance, (i)
the presence of well-defined pores and channels able to facilitate
the free passage of the amines, (ii) the presence of a π-electron-rich
ligand framework architecture for the possible π–π
stacking and other noncovalent interactions, (iii) the presence of
Lewis acidic metal sites, (iv) the existence of basic amide functionality,
and (v) their high thermal as well as solution stability along with
strong emission of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 in organic suspensions. It is worth noticing, that we have examined
the luminescence intensities of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 in several common organic solvents such as acetone, toluene,
tetrahydrofuran (THF), n-butanol (BuOH), ethyl acetate,
ethanol (EtOH), propanol, isopropanol, acetonitrile (ACN), dichloromethane
(DCM), methanol, chloroform, N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA), N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), aniline,
and water and noticed the strongest emission in aqueous suspensions
(Figure S12). Noticeably, the emission
intensity of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 increases
in most of the solvents, while it drastically decreases in the case
of aniline, which indicates that the fluorescence intensity is largely
reliant on the small molecules, and we fortified to explore these
materials as fluorescence-based molecular sensors for a wide range
of organic amines (). Further, this quenching in the emission intensity of sensors
Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 could be observed
by the naked eye as their colorless solution immediately changed to
reddish-brown (Figure S16).

elements.content: Based on the aforementioned observation, we have chosen aqueous medium as the dispersion medium to accomplish the organic amine sensing study. For this, we have employed a number of organic amines having different shapes, sizes, and functionalities, for instance, aniline (6.65 × 8.06 Å2); 2-aminopyridine (2-AP; 6.63 × 8.02 Å2); 3-aminopyridine (3-AP; 6.65 × 8.01 Å2); 4-aminopyridine (4-AP; 6.42 × 7.22 Å2); 2,6-diisopropyl aniline (2,6-DIPA; 8.08 × 11.20 Å2); 4-(aminomethyl)­pyridine (4-PA; 6.64 × 8.76 Å2); para-aminobenzoic acid (4-ABA; 6.68 × 9.31 Å2); cyclohexyl amine (CHA; 6.35 × 8.33 Å2); trans-cyclohexyldiamine (trans-CHDA; 6.75 × 8.56 Å2); dimethylamine (DMA; 3.80 × 6.62 Å2), diethylamine (di-EA; 3.80 × 9.91 Å2), triethylamine (TEA; 8.41 × 8.56 Å2); N′,N′-dimethylethane-1,2-diamine (N,N′-DMEDA; 6.42 × 6.63 Å2); N 1,N 1,N 2,N 2-tetramethylethane-1,2-diamine (TMED; 6.63 × 10.30 Å2); N 1,N 1,N 3,N 3-tetramethylpropane-1,3-diamine (TMPDA; 6.63 × 11.63 Å2); N 1-(2-aminoethyl)­ethane-1,2-diamine (DETA; 5.51 × 11.44 Å2); 2-aminoethanol (EA; 4.04 × 7.65 Å2); 2-((2-aminoethyl)­amino)­ethanol (N-(2HE)-ED; 4.93 × 11.31 Å2); 2,2′-azanediyldiethanol (DEA; 5.51 × 11.18 Å2); 2,2′,2″-nitrilotriethanol (TA; 10.10 × 10.10 Å2); and N′,N′-bis­(2-aminoethyl)­ethane-1,2-diamine (T-2-AEA; 8.79 × 11.43 Å2) and examined their quenching capability. Besides, to generalize and analyze the wider applicability of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 as molecular sensors, we have also investigated the quenching ability for some heterocyclic organic amines such as pyrimidine-2,4,6-triamine (2,4,6-TAP; 7.95 × 8.72 Å2) and chiral organic amines; (1R,2R)-1,2-diphenylethane-1,2-diamine ((1R,2R)-DPDA; 8.83 × 11.40 Å2); (1R,2R)-cyclohexane-1,2-diamine (1R,2R-CHDA; 6.74 × 7.42 Å2); and (1S,2S)-cyclohexane-1,2-diamine (1S,2S-CHDA; 7.43 × 8.34 Å2) (see Chart S1 and Table S4, for details).

elements.content: For this, each amine’s methanol solution (50 μL) was transferred to a 2 mL aqueous suspension of Zn-MOF-1 or Cd-MOF-2 (stock solution: 50 mg of Zn- or Cd-MOF in 250 mL of water), and fluorescence quenching behavior was observed. As shown in , almost all of the studied amine analytes showed quenching effects on Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 luminescence intensity to some extent, and the quenching effects follow the order 4-ABA > 2,6-DIPA > aniline > 2,4,6-TAP > 4-PA > 3-AP > DETA > N,N′-DMEDA > CHA > di-EA > TMED = TA = DMA = trans-CHDA > TEA = TMPDA > 2-AP = DEA > EA > N-(2HE)-ED > 4-AP > 1R,2R-CHDA = 1S,2S-CHDA = 1R,2R-DPDA > T-2-AEA for Zn-MOF-1 and 4-ABA > 2,6-DIPA > aniline > 2,4,6-TAP > EA > 4-AP > TMPDA > TA > trans-CHDA > DMA > N,N′-DMEDA > TEA > DETA > 2-AP = N-(2HE)-ED = TMED > di-EA > CHA > 4-PA > 3-AP = DEA > 1R,2R-CHDA > 1S,2S-CHDA > 1R,2R-DPDA > T-2-AEA for Cd-MOF-2. Excitingly, analytes 4-ABA (>98%), 2,6-DIPA (88%), and aniline (67%) exhibited the most tremendous quenching effects in Zn-MOF-1 and 4-ABA (>96%), 2,6-DIPA (77%), and aniline (72%) in Cd-MOF-2, among all of the investigated organic amines using the same concentration of the solution ().

elements.content: The quenching efficiency was calculated with the help of well-defined formula (I 0 – I)/I 0 × 100% (where I 0 is the original luminescence intensity of Zn-MOF-1 or Cd-MOF-2, while I is the luminescence intensity of Zn-MOF-1 or Cd-MOF-2 after the addition of the concerned analyte). Further, the quantitative quenching efficiency was calculated using the Stern–Volmer equation (I 0/I) = K SV[A] + 1, where K SV is the quenching constant [M–1] and [A] is the molar concentration of the concerned organic amine. However, the limit of detection (LOD) was calculated using the standard literature protocol, and their details are provided in the SI. In addition, K SV plots indicated a good linear relationship between the luminescence intensities and the concentrations of the concerned analytes at low concentrations ( and a–f) however slightly deviated from linearity at higher concentrations due to the static and dynamic quenching.

elements.content: The K SV values of Zn-MOF-1 for the detection of amines having the highest quenching effect are found to be 1.67 × 104 M–1 for 4-ABA, 3.59 × 103 M–1 for 2,6-DIPA, and 6.97 × 103 M–1 for aniline with the LOD values of 2.07, 6.76, and 13.97 μM for 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline, respectively. Similarly, for Cd-MOF-2, the K SV (and LOD) for the sensing of amines are estimated to be 4.60 × 104 M–1 (0.46 μM) for 4-ABA, 2.72 × 103 M–1 (1.10 μM) for aniline, and 4.07 × 103 M–1 (2.39 μM) for 2,6-DIPA. The high K SV values shown by Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 for the detection of organic amines are quite consistent with their respective quenching efficiencies ( and d–f, Table S5), whereas the LOD values imply excellent sensitivity, which is quite better than or comparable to the previously reported MOFs employed for organic amine sensing (Figures S17 and S18, Table S5). A comparative list of MOFs displaying comparable sensing ability is provided in Table S6 of the SI.

elements.content: In addition, we have also examined the quenching response time for the recognition of organic amines by performing time-dependent fluorescence titration employing sensor materials Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 and different concentrations of 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline. The plots between (%) quenching efficiency and exposure time are demonstrated in Figures S19 and S20. As revealed in Figures S19 and S20, the sensing of organic amines with Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 indicates a quick response time. For example, both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 show more than 98 and 96% of fluorescence quenching within 30 s of interaction time for analyte 4-ABA. This quick response time shown by Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 might be primarily attributed to the hydrogen-bonding and π–π stacking interactions, as both analytes and framework structures of sensors Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 contain π-electron-rich moieties along with the amidic functionality (sensor only). We further argue that the presence of H2O and DMF molecules in the cavities of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 assists the interactions between the guest analytes and the host framework.

elements.content: Further, to examine the specificity and selectivity of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 toward the deliberated amines, we have chosen 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline and performed a competition test, wherein a 2 mL suspension of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 was primarily added to 50 μL (50 mM solution) of respective amines, for instance, 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline followed by the addition of 50 μL (50 mM solution) of other possibly contending amines (apart from 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline) and studied their competitive activities, and the results are depicted in Figures S21 and S22 of the SI. It is important to mention that the primary emission intensity (blue bar) of sensors Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 was almost unaltered by the addition of other contending amines (red bar), thus signifying their detection ability and selectivity.

elements.content: To provide more wisdom about the binding interactions between amines and sensors Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, Benesi–Hildebrand (BH) experiments were performed, and their results are presented in Figures S23 and S24. The concerned BH plot shows that the detection of organic amines with Zn-MOF-1 demonstrates 1:1 binding stoichiometry with binding constant (K b) values of 3.59 × 10 –4, 1.09 × 10 –3, and 4.90 × 10 –4 M –1 for the recognition of 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline, respectively, with Zn-MOF-1. Similarly, Cd-MOF-2 also exhibits 1:1 binding stoichiometry with the K b values of 2.51 × 10 –3, 7.40 × 10 –4, and 3.68 × 10 –4 M –1 for the detection of 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline, respectively.

elements.content: Furthermore, it is important to find out the possible fluorescence quenching mechanism of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2. In principle, the fluorescence quenching of any molecular sensor/receptor might occur due to (i) disintegration of the framework architecture, (ii) nonclassical interactions between the host framework and the guest analytes, (iii) the absorption and resonance energy transfer (RET) between the host and guest, and (iv) photoinduced electron transfer (PET). To eliminate the first possibility, we have recorded PXRD patterns of the retrieved samples of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 after the sensing of 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline and compared with the pattern of fresh samples. These patterns are found to be very consistent, thereby suggesting that the basic framework integrity of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 remains intact even after the sensing and ruling out the hypothesis that quenching occurred due to the collapse of the basic structure.
elements.clean_text:
Furthermore, it is important to find out the possible fluorescence
quenching mechanism of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2. In principle, the fluorescence quenching of any molecular sensor/receptor
might occur due to (i) disintegration of the framework architecture,
(ii) nonclassical interactions between the host framework and the
guest analytes, (iii) the absorption and resonance energy transfer
(RET) between the host and guest, and (iv) photoinduced electron transfer
(PET). To eliminate the first possibility, we have recorded PXRD patterns
of the retrieved samples of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 after the sensing of 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline and compared
with the pattern of fresh samples. These patterns are found to be
very consistent, thereby suggesting that the basic framework integrity
of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 remains intact
even after the sensing and ruling out the hypothesis that quenching
occurred due to the collapse of the basic structure.

elements.content: Next, as discussed in the structural description, both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 feature a π-electron-rich framework along with the free amidic group and Lewis acidic metal sites. The presence of free amidic group and π-electrons in both the host framework and guest amines facilitates the π–π interactions, which might be resulting in quenching. Third, we have recorded the UV–vis absorption spectrum of all of the investigated amines along with Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, and their respective plots are depicted in Figures S25 and S26. As illustrated in Figures S25 and S26 and Table S7, the UV–vis absorption spectra of the organic amines do not exhibit significant integral orbital overlap {J(λ)} with the excitation spectra of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 in the wavelength range of 300–550 nm. Among all of the investigated organic amines, only the absorption of 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline show partial overlap with the excitation bands of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, which might absorb the energy of the excitation wavelength, thereby suggesting that sensing of the amines by Zn-MOF-1 or Cd-MOF-2 does not primarily occur via the RET mechanism.

elements.content: To examine the role of the PET mechanism in the fluorescence quenching phenomenon of amines, we have calculated the HOMO–LUMO energies along with their band gaps for all of the amine analytes by employing density functional theory (DFT) at the B3LYP level and compared these with those of ligand L. The details are provided in Figures S27 and S28 and Table S8 in the SI. The outcomes indicate that almost all of the analytes (except 4-ABA = −5.83 eV) do not exhibit a suitable LUMO location to accept the upcoming electron density from ligand L (−1.99 eV). We argue that the existence of a suitable LUMO position of 4-ABA might be one of the principal reasons for its highest quenching efficiency (>98% for Zn-MOF-1 and >96% for Cd-MOF-2), though the other analytes showing higher quenching efficiency such as 2,6-DIPA (>88 and 77%) and aniline (>67 and 72%) do not follow the aforementioned mechanistic route as their LUMO positions are quite high (0.39 eV for 2,6-DIPA and 0.35 eV for aniline) than that of ligand L. Based on the aforementioned mechanistic findings, we can argue that PET and RET are not the sole reasons to define the fluorescence quenching mechanism of amine sensing. Finally, we reason that the quenching of the fluorescence intensities of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 with the studied amines might be mainly instigated by the hydrogen-bonding and π–π interactions between aromatic amines and the host framework structure.

not exhibit a suitable LUMO location to accept the upcoming electron

of 4-ABA might be one of the principal reasons for its highest quenching

such as 2,6-DIPA (>88 and 77%) and aniline (>67 and 72%) do
not follow

argue that PET and RET are not the sole reasons to define the fluorescence

elements.content: To establish the stability of the framework structure of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 in solution, both were soaked in water as well as an organic (methanol and acetonitrile) solvent for 24 h at room temperature. After that, soaked samples were recovered and the integrity of their framework structure was examined with the help of FT-IR and PXRD analyses. As shown in Figure S29, the FT-IR spectra of the recovered samples closely match those of the freshly prepared samples of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2. In addition, the PXRD pattern of recovered samples is nicely fitted with the experimental pattern of the concerned MOF (Figure S29). These findings suggest that the framework structure of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 remains stable in the solution state. Further, we have also investigated the stability of the framework structure of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 after the sensing study. For this, we simply recollected the concerned sensors from the aqueous suspension after measuring the fluorescence and analyzed their structural reliability with the help of FT-IR and TGA, and their respective spectra and plots are depicted in Figures S30–S33. The concerned FT-IR spectra and TGA plots of the recovered samples match well with those of fresh samples of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, thereby proposing their structural reliability in aqueous suspensions.

Stability of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 in Solution
To establish the stability of the framework
structure of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 in solution,
both were soaked in water as well as an organic (methanol and acetonitrile)
solvent for 24 h at room temperature. After that, soaked samples were
recovered and the integrity of their framework structure was examined
with the help of FT-IR and PXRD analyses. As shown in Figure S29, the FT-IR spectra of the recovered
samples closely match those of the freshly prepared samples of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2. In addition, the PXRD pattern
of recovered samples is nicely fitted with the experimental pattern
of the concerned MOF (Figure S29). These
findings suggest that the framework structure of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 remains stable in the solution state. Further, we have also investigated the stability
of the framework structure of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 after the sensing study. For this, we simply recollected
the concerned sensors from the aqueous suspension after measuring
the fluorescence and analyzed their structural reliability with the
help of FT-IR and TGA, and their respective spectra and plots are
depicted in Figures S30–S33. The
concerned FT-IR spectra and TGA plots of the recovered samples match
well with those of fresh samples of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, thereby proposing their structural reliability in aqueous
suspensions.

elements.content: Additionally, to examine their crystallinity and phase purity, recyclability tests were carried out and are presented in Figure S34. Notably, sensors Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 display the same level of quenching efficiency even after five consecutive runs as observed for the fresh samples. The recovered samples after titration were employed for PXRD analysis, and their results are depicted in Figures S35 and S36. The unaltered PXRD patterns of recycled Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 demonstrate that the framework structure persisted even after five consecutive cycles of organic amine sensing. The recyclability experiments indicate that Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 can be exploited as potential fluorescence sensors for the organic amines in an aqueous solution.

elements.content: To provide more evidence to the above-said findings and eliminate the probability of leaching of metal ions from sensors Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 in the suspension during organic amine sensing, we employed the recycled samples along with the fresh samples for the ICP measurement and noticed only 0.70% of Zn2+ ions in the fresh samples (Table S9), whereas we did not observe any Cd2+ ions in the sample of Cd-MOF-2 (Table S9). The samples extracted after the fifth sequence of sensing of 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline exhibit only 0.18, 0.46, and 0.22% leaching of Zn2+ ions, respectively (Table S9). In contrast, the recycled samples of Cd-MOF-2 collected after the fifth cycle of sensing of 4-ABA, 2,6-DIPA, and aniline again do not display any leaching of Cd2+ ions (Table S9). These findings not only eliminate the probability of substantial leaching but also support our claim that the Zn2+ and Cd2+ sites endure with the framework structure of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 during sensing analysis and further strengthen our trust that luminescence quenching does not happen due to the breakdown of the MOF structure.

elements.content: A close look at the crystal structure of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 shows quite a few exciting features, for example, (i) the presence of Lewis acidic Zn2+ and Cd2+ metal sites in their framework, which can activate the substrate, (ii) uncoordinated amidic functionality that can act as basic sites and be able to stimulate the opening of the epoxide ring via holding the substrates in the cavity, (iii) the presence of channels (with cross sections of 7.10 × 33.02 Å2 in Zn-MOF-1 and 11.72 × 20.62 Å2 in Cd-MOF-2) that enable free diffusion of substrates to the catalytic sites, (iv) the presence of a π-electron-rich framework architecture that strengthens the structure and can facilitate the interactions between the catalytic framework and substrates/reagents, (v) high thermal stability, and (vi) the presence of labile water and DMF molecules in the cavities of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, respectively. These properties provide an excellent advantage to explore their catalytic activity toward the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 to epoxide. Initially, we have optimized the reaction conditions to achieve the maximum yield. For this, we have examined the influence of catalyst loading, temperature, solvent, presence of additives, the importance of cocatalyst, and other reaction factors by choosing styrene oxide and CO2 as model substrates for the studied cycloaddition reaction (see and S10 for details).

Fixation of
CO2 into Cyclic Carbonates
A
close look at the crystal structure of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 shows quite a few exciting features, for example, (i) the
presence of Lewis acidic Zn2+ and Cd2+ metal
sites in their framework, which can activate the substrate, (ii) uncoordinated
amidic functionality that can act as basic sites and be able to stimulate
the opening of the epoxide ring via holding the substrates in the
cavity, (iii) the presence of channels (with cross sections of 7.10
× 33.02 Å2 in Zn-MOF-1 and 11.72
× 20.62 Å2 in Cd-MOF-2) that enable
free diffusion of substrates to the catalytic sites, (iv) the presence
of a π-electron-rich framework architecture that strengthens
the structure and can facilitate the interactions between the catalytic
framework and substrates/reagents, (v) high thermal stability, and
(vi) the presence of labile water and DMF molecules in the cavities
of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, respectively.
These properties provide an excellent advantage to explore their catalytic
activity toward the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 to epoxide.
Initially, we have optimized the reaction conditions to achieve the
maximum yield. For this, we have examined the influence of catalyst
loading, temperature, solvent, presence of additives, the importance
of cocatalyst, and other reaction factors by choosing styrene oxide
and CO2 as model substrates for the studied cycloaddition
reaction (see  and S10 for details).

elements.content: The cycloaddition reaction between styrene oxide and CO2 in the presence of 0.5 mol % catalyst Zn-MOF-1 (in the absence of cocatalyst TBAB) afforded only a trace amount of the product even after 72 h at 25 °C (entry 1, ) under solvent-free conditions; however, it gave almost 17% of the respective cyclic carbonate after increasing the temperature from 25 to 45 °C (entry 2, ) in the same span of time. Further, the increment of loading of the cocatalyst from 0.5 to 1 mol % did not alter the reaction at 25 °C; however, it offered 42% product yield at 45 °C in 48 h (entries 3 and 4, respectively, ). The loading of the cocatalyst from 1 to 3 mol % displayed a slightly better yield (55%; entry 5, ). Notably, the further increment of the cocatalyst from 3 to 5 mol % does not considerably alter the product yield (entry 6, ).

The cycloaddition
reaction between styrene oxide and CO2 in the presence
of 0.5 mol % catalyst Zn-MOF-1 (in
the absence of cocatalyst TBAB) afforded only a trace amount of the
product even after 72 h at 25 °C (entry 1, ) under solvent-free conditions; however,
it gave almost 17% of the respective cyclic carbonate after increasing
the temperature from 25 to 45 °C (entry 2, ) in the same span of time. Further, the
increment of loading of the cocatalyst from 0.5 to 1 mol % did not
alter the reaction at 25 °C; however, it offered 42% product
yield at 45 °C in 48 h (entries 3 and 4, respectively, ). The loading of
the cocatalyst from 1 to 3 mol % displayed a slightly better yield
(55%; entry 5, ). Notably, the further increment of the cocatalyst from 3 to 5 mol
% does not considerably alter the product yield (entry 6, ).

elements.content: On the other hand, an increase in the catalyst Zn-MOF-1 loading from 0.5 to 1 mol % boosted the reaction efficiency and yielded 96% of the respective cyclic carbonate only in 24 h at 45 °C (entry 7, ). Further, in the thrust of better product yield, when we increased the reaction time from 24 to 48 h, the temperature from 45 to 70 °C (entries 7 and 8, ) did not alter the product yield significantly. In addition, the increment of catalyst loading from 1 to 3 to 5% did not improve the product yield (entries 8–10, ). To see the influence of solvent on the aforementioned cycloaddition reaction, we performed the reaction in ethanol and methanol one by one; however, we did not witness any enhancement in the product yield compared to solvent-free conditions (entries 11 and 12, ). After screening catalyst Zn-MOF-1, we screened catalyst Cd-MOF-2 under similar conditions and noticed almost identical results (entries 13–24, ). Therefore, the best conditions for cycloaddition reaction were found to be 1 mol % catalyst, 3 mol % cocatalyst, solvent-free conditions, 45 °C temperature, and 24 h time.

elements.content: Following optimized catalytic conditions for the CO2-to-epoxide cycloaddition, we examined the importance of catalysts Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, predominantly the role of their coordination framework structure, and some control experiments were performed, and the results are listed in Table S10. Primarily, a cycloaddition reaction was set up between CO2 and styrene oxide without Zn-MOF-1 or Cd-MOF-2 under our optimized reaction protocol. Noticeably, in the absence of catalyst Zn-MOF-1 or Cd-MOF-2, no reaction ensued even after extending the reaction time (entry 1, Table S10). Subsequently, various Zn2+ and Cd2+ salts were also scrutinized as catalysts under similar conditions.

elements.content: As shown in Table S10, Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O gave only 16% yield of the concerned cyclic carbonate in 24 h (entry 2, Table S10) of reaction time, while Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O and ZnCl2·xH2O offered 11 and 14% of product yield (entries 3 and 4, Table S10). On the other hand, in the presence of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O, the transformation of CO2 to cyclic carbonate did not take place (entry 5, Table S10). However, under similar reaction conditions, Cd­(OAc)2·2H2O and CdCl2·H2O yielded only a trace amount of the product (entries 6 and 7, Table S10). These outcomes strongly underlined the significance of the framework structure of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, which prompts to achieve 96 and 84% of cyclic carbonate in due course of time (entry 8, Table S10).

elements.content: From the aforesaid optimization assessments, the optimum yielding reaction conditions for the CO2-to-cyclic carbonate transformation are found to be 1.7 mmol styrene oxide, 1 mol % catalyst (Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2), 3 mol % cocatalyst, 45 °C temperature, 24 h time, and solvent-free conditions. Under similar reaction conditions, the substrate scope was examined, wherein a number of assorted epoxides were assessed in the presence of the Zn-MOF-1 or Cd-MOF-2/TBAB catalytic system, and the results are shown in . The product of these transformation reactions is well analyzed via 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy and mass spectrometry (Figures S37–S70). The CO2-to-propylene oxide cycloaddition reaction in the presence of catalyst Zn-MOF-1 afforded 72% of the corresponding cyclic carbonate within 24 h (entry 1, ) in our established reaction protocol. Similarly, 2,3-epoxy-1-propanol and epichlorohydrine gave 83 and 96% of the respective cyclic carbonate, respectively (entries 2 and 3, ). The better yield obtained in the case of epichlorohydrine might be due to the existence of an electron-withdrawing Cl group facilitating the interaction between the electron-rich coordination framework architecture of the catalyst and the substrate.

are found to be 1.7 mmol styrene oxide, 1 mol % catalyst (Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2), 3 mol % cocatalyst, 45 °C
temperature, 24 h time, and solvent-free conditions. Under similar
reaction conditions, the substrate scope was examined, wherein a number
of assorted epoxides were assessed in the presence of the Zn-MOF-1 or Cd-MOF-2/TBAB catalytic system, and the
results are shown in . The product of these transformation reactions is well analyzed
via 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy and mass spectrometry
(Figures S37–S70). The CO2-to-propylene oxide cycloaddition reaction in the presence of catalyst
Zn-MOF-1 afforded 72% of the corresponding cyclic carbonate
within 24 h (entry 1, ) in our established reaction protocol. Similarly, 2,3-epoxy-1-propanol
and epichlorohydrine gave 83 and 96% of the respective cyclic carbonate,
respectively (entries 2 and 3, ). The better yield obtained in the case of epichlorohydrine
might be due to the existence of an electron-withdrawing Cl group
facilitating the interaction between the electron-rich coordination
framework architecture of the catalyst and the substrate.

elements.content: Next, we have employed cyclopentene oxide and obtained nearly 80% of the corresponding cyclic carbonate (entry 4, ). Cyclohexene oxide also behaves properly and exhibited good yield (76%; entry 5, ). To see the impact of electronic environment and steric hindrance, we have employed a few epoxides having different electronic and steric influences, for instance, styrene oxide, phenyl glycidyl ether, glycidyl benzyl ether, and 2-tert-butyl-2-[2-(4-chlorophenyl)­ethyl]­oxirane. Under our established protocol, styrene oxide and phenyl glycidyl ether produce subsequent cyclic carbonates in good yields (96 and 87%, respectively) (entries 6 and 7, ). However, under similar reaction conditions, the bulkier glycidyl benzyl ether reacts quite slowly and afforded only 61% of the respective cyclic carbonate (entry 8, ).

Next, we have employed cyclopentene oxide and obtained nearly 80%
of the corresponding cyclic carbonate (entry 4, ). Cyclohexene oxide also behaves properly
and exhibited good  yield (76%; entry 5, ). To see the impact of electronic environment
and steric hindrance, we have employed a few epoxides having different
electronic and steric influences, for instance, styrene oxide, phenyl
glycidyl ether, glycidyl benzyl ether, and 2-tert-butyl-2-[2-(4-chlorophenyl)­ethyl]­oxirane. Under our established
protocol, styrene oxide and phenyl glycidyl ether produce subsequent
cyclic carbonates in good yields (96 and 87%, respectively) (entries
6 and 7, ).
However, under similar reaction conditions, the bulkier glycidyl benzyl
ether reacts quite slowly and afforded only 61% of the respective
cyclic carbonate (entry 8, ).

elements.content: Further, to perceive the influence of more crowding around the epoxide ring on the catalytic yield, we have employed sterically demanding 2-tert-butyl-2-[2-(4-chlorophenyl)­ethyl]­oxirane and performed the cycloaddition reaction. Remarkably, 2-tert-butyl-2-[2-(4-chlorophenyl)­ethyl]­oxirane afforded only 8% of the respective cyclic carbonate (entry 9, ). Notably, catalyst Cd-MOF-2 also works well under our established protocol and shows a somewhat similar yield of respective cyclic carbonates (entries 1–8, ). Notably, in the case of 2-tert-butyl-2-[2-(4-chlorophenyl)­ethyl]­oxirane, we could not observe any product formation even after the prolonged reaction time and elevated temperature (72 h, 80 °C). This poor performance shown by 2-tert-butyl-2-[2-(4-chlorophenyl)­ethyl]­oxirane might be due to the presence of steric crowding around the epoxide ring. Nevertheless, these findings indicate that the terminal epoxides behave nicely in our established protocol and afforded the respective cyclic carbonates in good yields. The better conversion shown by small-sized epoxides might be due to their easy passage to the catalytic sites compared to bulky and sterically hindered epoxide.

elements.content: It is clear from the above-said findings that the product yield is closely associated with the electronic and steric factors of the concerned epoxide. The catalytic efficiency shown by our catalysts Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 are reasonably better/comparable to the other CPs /MOFs employed for the CO2-to-epoxide cycloaddition reported in the literature. A comparative list of the CP/MOF-catalyzed CO2-to-epoxide cycloaddition reaction is provided in Table S11 of the SI.

elements.content: To investigate the real-time monitoring of the CO2-to-cyclic carbonate transformation reaction, we have performed time-dependent NMR spectroscopy. For this, we have selected Zn-MOF-1 as a catalyst and the CO2-to-styrene oxide cycloaddition reaction as an exemplary reaction to monitor the progress of the reaction. The experiment established that the time-bound NMR technique can screen the consumption of starting material, i.e., styrene oxide, and the formation of respective cyclic carbonate product (4-phenyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-onecyclic) while also indicating the presence of unreacted portion ( and ). Notably, the characteristic signals of the −CH2– protons (Ha, δ2.98–3.00 ppm; and Hb, δ2.65–2.67 ppm) of the styrene oxide start disappearing as the time increases.

elements.content: Similarly, the methine (>CH−) signal (Hc, δ3.72–3.74 ppm) of the styrene oxide also starts shifting as the conversion of cyclic carbonate is instigated. Simultaneously, the new signals related to the cyclic carbonate product (Hd, δ4.35–4.39 ppm; He, δ4.81–4.85 ppm; Hf, δ5.68–5.72 ppm) start appearing (1 h, conversion, 9%), which could be seen in the concerned spectrum (). Noticeably, 1H NMR signals for Ha, Hb, and Hc related to styrene oxide disappear after 24 h. Further, we have integrated the signals of the NMR spectra recorded for the reaction mixture after a time interval, for instance, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 16, and 24 h, for the quantification, which displayed 25, 28, 40, 66, 76, 82, and 96%, respectively. The presence of starting material styrene oxide as well as the respective cyclic carbonate product instantaneously could be seen in the intermediate spectrum recorded after 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, and 16 h, respectively.

elements.content: In the same way, the 13C NMR spectrum of styrene oxide displays the characteristic signals for the C1 and C2 carbon associated with the epoxide ring at δ51.12 and δ52.31 ppm, respectively. On the other hand, the appearance of the carbonyl carbon (C9, CO; δ154.84 ppm) signal of the cyclic carbonate product could be seen in the spectrum recorded after 1 h (). Besides, the 13C NMR spectrum recorded after 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, and 16 h exhibits the signals for the starting styrene oxide and cyclic carbonate collectively. Notably, the characteristic signals for the C1 and C2 carbon of styrene oxide completely disappear after 24 h. It is also important to mention that the other notable signals for C10 (δ71.21 ppm) and C11 (δ78.05 ppm) could be also seen in the concerned spectrum collected after 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 16, and 24 h. Notably, we could not detect any side product in these 1H and 13C NMR spectra; this might be due to the low concentration or their poor solubility in the organic solvent. In addition, the results of both 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy analyses indicate that the CO2-to-cyclic carbonate transformation reaction smoothly took place in the presence of our catalysts and our established protocol.

elements.content: A linear plot of ln­([SO]0/[SO]) against time gave a k obs value of 0.18754, which reveals first-order dependence on SO (Figure S71). Therefore, we can argue that the conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonate under our established protocol follows an overall pseudo-first-order kinetics. A similar observation is also noticed in the literature for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide.

elements.content: The possible mechanism for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide in the presence of Lewis acidic transition-metal ions and quaternary ammonium salts such as TBAB or TBAI as cocatalysts are well explored in the literature. Therefore, based on the literature findings, we have also described a probable mechanism for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide in the presence of our catalyst Zn-MOF-1 (representative one) and cocatalyst TBAB in . As shown in , initially, epoxide interacts with the Lewis acidic Zn center through the {−O−} atom and activates the ring. Herein, epoxide ring-opening is assisted by Zn2+ sites, resulting in the formation of oxygen···Zn adducts (I). In the second step, the Br– generated from TBAB attacks as nucleophiles on the sterically less-crowded carbon atom to break the three-membered epoxide ring (II). In the third step, the insertion of CO2 and formation of alkyl carbonate anion (III) took place, which consequently endures intramolecular ring closure to produce the cyclic carbonate product (IV) and revival of catalytic systems (Zn-MOF-1 or Cd-MOF-2/TBAB), which could be used for the next cycles. Notably, channels present in the concern catalysts Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 assist the unrestricted passage of substrates to the catalytic sites, thus also helping in the better yield of cyclic carbonate.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanistic Insights into
the Fixation of CO2 to
Cyclic Carbonate
The possible mechanism for the cycloaddition
of CO2 to epoxide in the presence of Lewis acidic transition-metal
ions and quaternary ammonium salts such as TBAB or TBAI as cocatalysts
are well explored in the literature. Therefore, based on the literature findings, we have
also described a probable mechanism for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide in the presence of our catalyst Zn-MOF-1 (representative one) and cocatalyst TBAB in . As shown in , initially, epoxide interacts with the Lewis
acidic Zn center through the {−O−} atom and activates
the ring. Herein, epoxide ring-opening is assisted by Zn2+ sites, resulting in the formation of oxygen···Zn
adducts (I). In the second
step, the Br– generated from TBAB attacks as nucleophiles
on the sterically less-crowded carbon atom to break the three-membered
epoxide ring (II). In the third step, the insertion of
CO2 and formation of alkyl carbonate anion (III) took place, which consequently endures intramolecular ring closure
to produce the cyclic carbonate product (IV) and revival
of catalytic systems (Zn-MOF-1 or Cd-MOF-2/TBAB), which could be used for the next cycles. Notably, channels
present in the concern catalysts Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 assist the unrestricted passage of substrates to the catalytic
sites, thus also helping in the better yield of cyclic carbonate.

elements.content: Further, shows that the epoxide having a smaller size shows better conversion compared to the bulky and sterically hindered epoxide. To support this statement, BET isotherms and pore size distribution plots for Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 were also analyzed, and the results are depicted in Figure S72. The N2 sorption isotherm suggested that Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 exhibit BET surface areas of 61 and 8 m2/g along with the pore volumes of 0.038 and 0.072 cm3/g, respectively. Nevertheless, these results proposed the microporous nature of the studied MOFs. We reasoned that the low surface area shown by Cd-MOF-2 might be due to the presence of a bulky DMF molecule inside the pore and a disordered ligand arm that filled the available channel in the framework, which is also reflected in its lower conversion rate than that of Zn-MOF-1. The presence of uncoordinated amidic functionality in the structure of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 not only holds the catalytic substrates and reagents (epoxides and CO2) inside the channels through the hydrogen-bonding interactions but also assisted in its activation.

elements.content: The recyclability and heterogeneous nature of the catalyst are essential aspects to be considered for commercial submissions. To confirm the heterogeneous nature of catalysts Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, we have recovered the concerned catalyst after the cycloaddition of CO2 to styrene oxide and characterized it with the help of FT-IR, TGA, and PXRD analyses (Figures S73–S78). Notably, both catalysts Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 are reproducible for up to five consecutive cycles without perceiving any substantial loss in their catalytic efficiency (inset of and S79) and, thus, their catalytic outcome (entry 6, ). The FT-IR spectra and PXRD patterns of the recovered samples of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 are closely accorded with those of the fresh samples, thus suggesting structure integrity postcatalysis (Figures S73, S74 and S77, S78).

elements.content: The TG curve of the recovered samples also nicely fits with the curve recorded before catalysis, thereby suggesting that the mechanical force generated during the stirring and other applied reaction conditions could not disintegrate the original structure (Figures S75 and S76). Further, to probe the heterogeneity of catalysts Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2, a leaching experiment was performed. For this, a control CO2-to-styrene oxide cycloaddition reaction was carried out in the presence of catalyst Zn-MOF-1 (representative one) in our established protocol and is described in . As discussed in , the substrate conversion is terminated after the removal of the catalyst after 4 h. Further, the re-employment of the catalyst after 10 h resulted in resuming of catalysis, leading to completeness. The leaching of the Zn2+ and Cd2+ species from the concerned catalyst was examined with the help of ICP-MS analysis.

All of the aforementioned investigations clearly suggested that our catalysts Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 act well for the fixation of greenhouse CO2 gas to cyclic carbonate in our established protocol.

elements.content: In summary, two new Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 have been prepared and structurally characterized. The concerned crystal structure of Zn-MOF-1 displays an overall 3D framework structure having a uninodal sql topology and 2D + 2D, parallel polycatenation, whereas the crystal packing of Cd-MOF-2 adopted an overall (3,4)-connected porous framework architecture. Further, both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 were exploited as multifunctional materials to detect organic amines and in the fixation of CO2 to cyclic carbonates. Remarkably, Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 displayed a maximum of 98 and 97% quenching efficiency for 4-ABA, respectively. The mechanistic study of the recognition of organic amines proposed that fluorescence quenching is primarily facilitated by the hydrogen-bonding and π–π stacking interactions. Additionally, cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide in the presence of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 offered up to 96% desired product yield in 24 h. Notably, both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 are recyclable for up to five successive runs without a substantial loss in their productivity. The findings of the present investigation will open new avenues for contemporary researchers in designing and building multifunctional MOFs with an anticipated solution to the environmental problems being faced by society in the near future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
In summary, two new Zn-MOF-1 and
Cd-MOF-2 have been prepared and structurally characterized.
The concerned
crystal structure of Zn-MOF-1 displays an overall 3D
framework structure having a uninodal sql topology and
2D + 2D, parallel polycatenation, whereas the crystal packing of Cd-MOF-2 adopted an overall (3,4)-connected porous framework architecture.
Further, both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 were
exploited as multifunctional materials to detect organic amines and
in the fixation of CO2 to cyclic carbonates. Remarkably,
Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 displayed a maximum
of 98 and 97% quenching efficiency for 4-ABA, respectively. The mechanistic
study of the recognition of organic amines proposed that fluorescence
quenching is primarily facilitated by the hydrogen-bonding and π–π
stacking interactions. Additionally, cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide in the presence of Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 offered up to 96% desired product yield in 24 h. Notably,
both Zn-MOF-1 and Cd-MOF-2 are recyclable
for up to five successive runs without a substantial loss in their
productivity. The findings of the present investigation will open
new avenues for contemporary researchers in designing and building
multifunctional MOFs with an anticipated solution to the environmental
problems being faced by society in the near future.
